captions.text: Second Wind
[Intro Music]

It&#39;s a shame that being a straight white 
Northern European dude means I don&#39;t get

a special holiday every year celebrating the time 
when my country was liberated from people like me,

but I can always take solace in the fact 
that the entire world literally exists for

my benefit. And if I&#39;m bored I can just go sail 
to some exotic land and take all their spice,

and proceed to not use it because it smells weird. 
And it&#39;s also gratifying to know that the current

nostalgic wave of retro early 3D styled games is 
squarely aimed at appealing to me and evoking all

the classic PC gaming golden age FPSes I played 
the shit out of in the 90s. But at the same time,

it also makes things impossibly awkward 
if I don&#39;t like them. &#39;Cos I mean, who the

hell else is going to appreciate it&#39;s heavily 
pixellated brown textures, besides scat fetish

lego enthusiasts? &quot;We made this just for you!&quot; 
cry the creators, like a grandmother brandishing

a new Christmas scarf, except it&#39;s made entirely 
of brown-ish grey wool and it&#39;s got the word

&quot;Retard&quot; stitched into it because that&#39;s the kind 
of transgression you 90s kids find hilarious,

isn&#39;t it? Thanks, grandma, I&#39;ll play it every 
day. Oh god, why did I say that? Now I need to

make sure it&#39;s in my Steam recently played 
list every time she fucking comes round.

So we&#39;ve had our nostalgic Doom ripoff with 
Prodeus and our nostalgic Blood ripoff with

Cultic, but we still didn&#39;t have our nostalgic 
Hexen ripoff, so here comes Graven to fill the

niche. Named after how a road accident victim 
with a speech impediment might describe the

drab coloured commercial vehicle that hit him - 
yeah sorry that&#39;s the best I&#39;ve got - in Graven

we play as a bearded murder priest who had a 
daughter or something who some other murder

priest tried to murder, getting really confused 
as to why we&#39;d have a problem with that, I mean,

we&#39;re murder priests, dude, you should&#39;ve 
read the sign over the door. And after a big

kerfuffle we&#39;re exiled from our order and find 
ourselves lost in a stricken land full of death,

monsters and brown. To it&#39;s credit, 
Graven gets the mandatory 90&#39;s FPS

sewer level out of the way right at the 
start, and then just in case you miss it,

proceeds to carve the rest of the game out 
of shit. I only remembered the whole plot

point with the daughter because at the end of 
the first act there was a cutscene with your

boy going &quot;This land was safe but I was no 
closer to learning the fate of my daughter.&quot;

And I was all like &quot;Oh yeah. Plots. I remember 
those. I completely forgot about the fucking

daughter thing &#39;cos I&#39;ve spent the last twelve 
hours going back and forth across greenish-brown

wildernesses trying to figure out where in John 
Romero&#39;s forsaken haircare regimen I was supposed

to go next. Thanks for reminding me of the plot 
by informing me that it hasn&#39;t budged forward a

fucking inch. See, Hexen was a pioneer in that it 
was one of the first FPSes to embrace hub-based

exploration and backtracking, but this was also 
in the era when FPS level designers fell back on

keyhunting every time their mountain dew glass was 
empty, and Hexen was all like &quot;What if, instead of

having to backtrack across a samey labyrinthine 
map looking for the door opened by the key you

just found, you had to backtrack across nine 
of the fuckers?&quot; And that&#39;s the spirit Graven

is keen to evoke. All progress was tainted by the 
knowledge that it was only a matter of time before

my next walking tour of the entire fucking game to 
date trying to figure out where the cocking Turtle

Key goes. Turned out it was underwater. Oh, sorry. 
I was kind of getting the message to stay out of

water &#39;cos it was the colour of diarrhoea and 
visibility was poor and there was no air and it

was full of huge fleshy carnivorous eels trying 
to start a conversation with my enormous knob.

I get the sense that Graven is one of those games 
that tries to hide behind the deliberately retro

thing. &quot;Of course there&#39;s no map. Where do you 
think you are, fuckin&#39; Six Flags? In our day,

we drew our own map, and that&#39;s how we liked 
it. Oh, I expect you wanted a fucking objective

marker instead of having to deduce where to 
go from dialogue and context clues like we

expect you to have more intelligence than a 
chimp with a banana dangling in front of its

face.&quot; I might give you more of a pass, Graven, 
if the dialogue in question wasn&#39;t usually along

the lines of &quot;go to that weird house behind the 
bike sheds&quot; when said house is in the middle of

a hedge maze and the bike sheds are locked 
by a machine that&#39;s missing three gears,

two of which are in different buildings and 
one in a particularly hard to notice borough

of Inverness. But fine, okay, I mean, Hexen 
wouldn&#39;t even have had that amount of text.

What I&#39;m pretty sure nobody liked in any 
era of gaming is the combat being shitty,

and Graven can&#39;t banana dangle its way out 
of that one. Initially it&#39;s melee focussed,

with our boy having to see off shambling groups of 
zombies with corrective taps of the walking stick.

Which isn&#39;t much fun because enemies don&#39;t so much 
attack as briefly get seized by the urge to do the

Thriller dance, and if you&#39;re close enough to 
read their name tag you just lose a third of

your health. Later on the combat gets more range 
focused. You&#39;ll know, because you&#39;ll be hit in the

face with a blast of toxic snot from the fucking 
flying lizard thing fifteen miles away that you

mistook for a speck of dust on your contact lens. 
Your own ranged weapons start with a wrist-mounted

dart launcher with all the satisfying sound and 
action of a queefing stick insect and a variety

of crossbows and ballistas that for god know&#39;s 
what reason all take up four slots on the quick

select panel. Which doesn&#39;t mean you can&#39;t 
use them, you just have to pause the game

and rearrange your whole inventory every time 
you need to switch, and I have no clue why this

has to be the case unless it&#39;s to prevent your 
healing potions from getting bedsores. There&#39;s

no room on the quick select for more than one of 
the actually useful guns since I also needed room

for my sword and potions and it wouldn&#39;t let 
me unequip my walking stick or my magic book.

Yeah, while we&#39;re on the subject, Graven 
severely overestimates how much I&#39;d want

to use that fucking magic book. &quot;Oh I see 
you&#39;re still full on mana restoring potions,

but here&#39;s some more anyway in case you miss 
the fact that mana refills are coming out

of the fucking walls.&quot; And then your magic fire 
attack feels more like very threateningly holding

out a cigarette lighter. I think overall Graven 
illustrates that nostalgia is all very well but

there are certain quality of life improvements 
I&#39;d rather not go back to life without. Like a

colour palette that means you can tell the 
difference between explodey barrels and the

regular kind when you&#39;re blindly smashing up 
the furniture looking for potions in low light

conditions. Level design that&#39;s more intuitive 
than trying to identify rabbit turds in a bowl of

chocolate covered raisins. Incredibly dramatically 
introduced boss fights that do more than just sit

there while you systematically carve off their 
seventeen purple tits. As L.P. Hartley once wrote,

the past is a foreign country. Presumably one 
of the ones where you can only buy music on

cassette tapes and women aren&#39;t allowed to 
own shoes. It&#39;s nice to visit now and then

but one soon grows tired of being woken in the 
morning by the musical trill of dial-up modems.
